   <title>
    What is data sovereignty and why does it matter for your business?
   </title>
   <link/>
   https://proton.me/blog/data-sovereignty
   <guid ispermalink="true">

   </guid>
   <description>
    This article will explain data sovereignty, why it matters, and how it can be achieved to not only protect you, but your business.
   </description>
   <pubdate>
    Fri, 12 Jul 2024 22:13:34 GMT
   </pubdate>
   <content:encoded>
    <p>People and companies are generally subject to the laws of the country and city where they are located, and those laws can change when they move to a new place. However, the situation becomes more complicated when considering data, which can be subject to multiple jurisdictions depending on where it is collected, processed, and stored.</p>



<p>If you live in France, for example, and a US tech company stores your data in servers located in California, which laws are relevant to your most valuable information?</p>



<p>The answer to that question is becoming more important every day, as more and more people interact with products, apps, and programs from all over the globe. The central principle of<strong> data sovereignty </strong>is that<strong> data should be subject to the laws of the country where it was generated and collected</strong>.&nbsp;</p>



<p>As the ongoing saga over how <a href="https://noyb.eu/en/european-commission-gives-eu-us-data-transfers-third-round-cjeu">Meta processes Europeans’ data</a>  demonstrates, however,&nbsp;this concept is being challenged. How data sovereignty is applied — or not — to your data will have a lasting impact on the internet as a whole.&nbsp;</p>



<p>This article will explain the concept, why it matters, and how it can be achieved so your business remains secure and compliant with the strictest of data sovereignty regulations. </p>



<ul>
<li><strong><a href="#what-is">What is data sovereignty?</a></strong></li>



<li><strong><a href="#which-laws">Which laws apply to my data?&nbsp;</a></strong></li>



<li><strong><a href="#who-opposes">Who opposes data sovereignty?</a></strong></li>



<li><strong><a href="#why-data">Why data sovereignty matters: The Meta case</a></strong></li>



<li><strong><a href="#best-practices">Best practices for your business</a></strong></li>



<li><strong><a href="#proton">Proton’s approach</a></strong></li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="what-is">What is data sovereignty?</h2>



<p>Many people tend to think of data as an abstract concept, a nebulous collection of personal data points that exists in space that is ill-defined. In reality, however, there are concrete statements we can make about most data to better understand where it is being stored:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Your data comes with fairly exact metadata:</strong> This information can pinpoint when and where it was collected, which format it is encoded in, and an identifier linked to the person or device where it originated</li>



<li><strong>Data is always stored somewhere in the physical world:</strong> This information occupies a well-defined physical space, measured in bytes on a computer or server.&nbsp;</li>



<li><strong>A large portion of data comes from your devices:</strong> It may be no surprise that <a href="https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2023/04/charted-there-are-more-phones-than-people-in-the-world/">there are more mobile phones in the world than people</a>. That’s why data generation and collection tend to start on your device before it is sent to another location — such as <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-the-cloud">the cloud</a> or remote servers — to be processed and stored.</li>
</ul>



<p>All that data is often generated in one country and stored in another, which raises an important question.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="which-laws">Which laws apply to my data?</h3>



<p>This is where <strong>data sovereignty</strong> enters the picture. Data sovereignty is <strong>the concept that it doesn’t matter where the data is stored — the laws that should govern data are the laws of the country where the data was generated and collected.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p>



<p>This makes intuitive sense. These are the same laws that also govern, in most cases, the person who generated the data. Why would it be different for their data?</p>



<p>The immediate consequence of data sovereignty for a company that collects and stores people’s data, however, is that it must adopt data governance policies and technical measures to ensure the legal protections governing that data are respected and implemented.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="who-opposes">Who opposes data sovereignty? </h3>



<p>Some of the staunchest critics of data sovereignty are  cloud storage providers. Their business model depends on selling cold storage, computing power, or whole backend infrastructures to companies.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Their physical servers are often located in countries outside their client&#8217;s jurisdiction — or they might reside in the same country as the client company while the cloud provider is headquartered in a different country.</p>



<p>If data sovereignty is enforced, these companies must meet new obligations, which can increase their overhead and complicate their workflows.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="why-data">Why data sovereignty matters: The Meta case</h2>



<p>Meta’s attempts to collect and process the data of people in the European Union and resulting lawsuits perfectly demonstrate the idea of data sovereignty.&nbsp;</p>



<p>In 2023, the EU <a href="https://apnews.com/article/meta-facebook-data-privacy-fine-europe-9aa912200226c3d53aa293dca8968f84">fined Meta a record $1.3 billion</a> in a <a href="https://apnews.com/article/data-privacy-europe-business-government-surveillance-technology-32cd88d05897f31e5b4d1bcd3d1ade83">decadeslong court case</a> and ordered it to cease sending users’ personal data across the Atlantic.</p>



<p>In a nutshell: Meta transferred all the data it collects from EU countries to its servers in the US so that it could process it and use it to sell ads. Thanks to data sovereignty protections in the <a href="https://gdpr.eu/what-is-gdpr/">GDPR</a>, all data that is collected from people in the EU must be processed and stored within the EU. </p>



<p>Max Schrems, founder of the <a href="https://noyb.eu/en">European Center for Digital Rights</a> (NOYB), argued that Meta and the <a href="https://noyb.eu/en/eu-us-data-transfers-0">US government do not meet the GDPR’s standard of protection</a>, as it <a href="https://proton.me/blog/us-warrantless-surveillance">implements mass surveillance programs</a> and has the ability to force US companies to share information they’ve collected.&nbsp;</p>



<p>The Court of Justice of the European Union agreed, and the litigation has shifted to finding an appropriate solution. None of this would be possible, however, if it weren&#8217;t for the principle of data sovereignty. If data collected in the EU no longer fell within the parameters of EU law, Schrems and NOYB would not have been able to make a strong case, much less win.&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="best-practices">Best practices for your business</h2>



<p>If you run a small business, having all your storage and computation needs fulfilled by an on-premise infrastructure — and therefore not relying on any contractor servers — is a possible way of achieving data sovereignty.</p>



<p>This is hardly cost-effective and efficient, however, for many businesses, especially smaller ones. Here are some alternative solutions and other best practices to consider:&nbsp;</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Conduct a data audit:</strong> Regularly assess where and how your data is stored and processed. This is a vital step that companies often overlook. Understanding the flow of data inside your organization can help identify potential compliance issues and areas where there is room for improvement.</li>



<li><strong>Use end-to-end encrypted email services</strong>: Ensure that all data communication methods and storage solutions use end-to-end encryption. This provides a robust layer of security, protecting data both at rest and in transit. Proton, for example, offers a comprehensive range of services that deploys both <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-end-to-end-encryption">end-to-end encryption</a> and <a href="https://proton.me/blog/zero-access-encryption">zero-access encryption</a> to allow you to remain compliant and secure. When you use <a href="https://proton.me/mail">Proton Mail</a>, your messages are automatically end-to-end encrypted — you don’t need to do anything.</li>



<li><strong>Use a privacy-first cloud provider:</strong> Choose cloud service providers that prioritize privacy and comply with data sovereignty laws. <a href="https://proton.me/drive">Proton Drive</a>, for example, can support businesses in meeting those requirements. End-to-end encryption and the protections of Swiss privacy laws will ensure your data is secure and shielded from unauthorized access.</li>
</ol>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="proton">Proton’s approach</h2>



<p>When you team up with Proton, you are protecting your business data so that no one, not even Proton, can access it. The keys to your most valuable information will remain in your possession at all times, ensuring your data meets the strictest data sovereignty regulations.</p>

<p><a href="https://proton.me/mail">Proton Mail</a>, our end-to-end encrypted email, and <a href="https://proton.me/drive">Proton Drive</a>, our end-to-end encrypted cloud storage service, make it easy to meet data protection and privacy requirements.&nbsp;</p>

   <title>
    Is your data safe from Google Docs AI scraping?
   </title>
   <link/>
   https://proton.me/blog/google-docs-ai-scraping

    https://proton.me/blog/google-docs-ai-scraping
   </guid>
   <description>
    Find out how to use AI in Google Docs and how to prevent your data from being used for AI training.
   </description>
   <pubdate>
    Fri, 12 Jul 2024 15:49:38 GMT
   </pubdate>
   <content:encoded>
    <p>Your online data is no longer just used for ads but also for <a href="https://proton.me/blog/privacy-and-chatgpt">training AI</a>. Google uses publicly available information to train its AI models, raising concerns over whether <a href="https://proton.me/blog/ai-gdpr">AI is even compatible with data protection laws</a>.</p>



<p>People are worried companies are scraping their personal files and data without their consent or outright stealing their copyrighted materials, as highlighted by the <a href="https://www.ftc.gov/policy/advocacy-research/tech-at-ftc/2023/10/consumers-are-voicing-concerns-about-ai" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">FTC</a>. You may begin to wonder whether any of your content is safe — including your writings and other drafts in Google Docs.</p>



<p>Currently Google Docs says it does not scrape data for AI training purposes, but the company does scan your data and use it in various other ways. Moreover, its <a href="https://policies.google.com/privacy#europeanrequirements" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">privacy policy</a> doesn’t explicitly rule out the possibility of using your data for AI in the future. </p>



<p>This article explores how Google Docs integrates with Gemini, its large language model (LLM), and whether your data is safe from Google Docs AI scraping for training purposes. We also share how to protect your data from being used to train AI and which <a href="https://proton.me/drive/docs">online document editor</a> you can use for privacy.</p>



<ul>
<li><a href="#google-docs-ai">How Google Docs uses AI</a></li>



<li><a href="#google-docs-scraping">Is Google Docs scraping your data?</a></li>



<li><a href="#docs-in-proton-drive">Protect your data from AI training with Docs in Proton Drive</a></li>



<li><a href="#defend-your-privacy">Proton defends your online privacy</a></li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="google-docs-ai">How Google Docs uses AI</h2>



<p>Google Docs uses machine learning to offer spelling suggestions, voice typing, comment reply suggestions, and even completing documents (this last feature, Smart Compose, is only available for work or school Google accounts). You can enable or turn off these AI features by clicking <strong>Tools → Preferences</strong> in a Google Doc.</p>



<p>Google also has an AI assistant called Gemini that can handle all types of tasks. It’s currently working on integrating Gemini into Google Docs (if you’re a member of Google Workspace Labs, you can get early access). It goes beyond autocomplete and can be used for suggesting text, improving grammar, providing style recommendations, and even generating or clarifying content ideas.</p>



<p>Google’s various AI tools are clearly a big part of Google Docs’ future, which might leave you wondering what this all means for the information in your documents?</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">What is Google Document AI?</h3>



<p>A quick clarification — Google also offers Google Document AI, which is an entirely different type of AI feature that allows users to quickly extract data, summarize it, and automate other tedious tasks that involve processing large amounts of documents and PDFs using artificial intelligence. Google specifically <a href="https://cloud.google.com/document-ai/docs/security-cmek-logging#data-usage" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">says</a> it doesn&#8217;t use customer data to train its Document AI models.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="google-docs-scraping">Is Google Docs AI scraping your data?</h2>



<p>Although Google says it does not use your Google Docs data to train its AI, Google&#8217;s privacy policy doesn&#8217;t explicitly stop the company from using your content and any other publicly available information to train their AI models. Moreover, there’s no easy way to verify that Google’s models don’t use public data since <a href="https://opening-up-chatgpt.github.io/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Google doesn’t disclose what data its models use</a>.</p>



<p>Google claims your documents and data are secure when using its AI features, stating that it doesn’t share any part of your document externally. While Google has security protocols in place, including encryption at rest and in transit, it doesn’t support end-to-end encryption, so Google itself has access to your data. Gemini and Google Docs are not open source, so there’s no way to verify the code does what Google claims, which means you’re left with no choice than trusting them to protect your privacy.</p>



<p>Additionally, Google Docs allows third-party extensions, which have their own privacy policies and may scrape or share your data. Be sure to check their permissions and privacy policies before granting any outside developers access to your documents.</p>



<p>If you want to be completely sure your data is private, the only sure solution is to <a href="https://proton.me/blog/how-to-de-google">stop using Google services</a>.</p>



<p>Additionally, you should make sure your documents are not set to <strong>Anyone with the link</strong> can view or edit. If that’s the case then if your document becomes publicly available, the information it contains will likely be used by Google and other AI services for AI training. </p>



<p>If you use Gemini, you should know it stores your queries and its outputs by default. However, it does allow you to permanently delete your chats and change its settings to prevent future ones from being stored or used for AI training.</p>



<p><a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-encryption">End-to-end encryption</a> is the best way to protect your content from this. Even if your data is stored, it cannot be read or used for training AI without your explicit permission.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="docs-in-proton-drive">Protect your data from AI training with Docs in Proton Drive</h2>



<p>Proton Drive now offers Docs, a secure and private alternative to Google Docs for creating and collaborating on online documents. Docs has all the features you expect from an online document editor, enabling you to:</p>



<ul>
<li>See the live cursors of your team members and their edits in real time</li>



<li>Gather feedback and share ideas with comments</li>



<li>Invite anyone to view or edit your docs</li>
</ul>



<p>However, unlike Google Docs and other online document editors, we use <a href="https://proton.me/security/end-to-end-encryption">end-to-end encryption</a> to protect your information. With Docs, the documents you create, their version history, any notes you add, and even your keystrokes and cursor movements are all end-to-end encrypted, so they can never be fed into AI models without your permission. Like all Proton services, Docs gives you the keys to access your files so no one — not even Proton — can access them without your consent.</p>



<p>Get started with <a href="https://proton.me/drive">Proton Drive for free</a> to encrypt your data and protect it from AI training.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Proton defends your online privacy</h2>



<p>Unlike Google, Proton doesn&#8217;t profit from your data. Instead, we are exclusively supported by our paying subscribers and primarily <a href="https://proton.me/blog/proton-non-profit-foundation">owned by a nonprofit</a> dedicated to promoting online privacy.</p>



<p>Since Proton is <a href="https://proton.me/blog/switzerland">located in Switzerland</a>, we adhere to some of the world&#8217;s strongest privacy laws. Furthermore, all our apps are <a href="https://proton.me/community/open-source">open source</a> and independently audited.</p>



<p>By signing up for a Proton account, you gain access to a secure ecosystem that protects all your data, including <a href="https://proton.me/drive">cloud storage</a>, <a href="https://proton.me/pass">passwords</a>, <a href="https://protonvpn.com/?ref=prdmenuvpn">internet connection</a>, <a href="https://proton.me/mail">email</a>, and <a href="https://proton.me/calendar">calendar</a>.</p>

   <title>
    How to manage passwords on iPhone and improve your security
   </title>
   <link/>
   https://proton.me/blog/find-delete-passwords-on-iphone
   <guid ispermalink="true">
    https://proton.me/blog/find-delete-passwords-on-iphone
   </guid>
   <description>
    Learn how to find, edit, and delete your passwords on iPhone and how to improve your security with an encrypted password manager.
   </description>
   <pubdate>
    Fri, 12 Jul 2024 14:57:39 GMT
   </pubdate>
   <content:encoded>
    <p>iPhone stores passwords in iCloud Keychain, Apple’s built-in password manager. It’s convenient but has <a href="https://proton.me/blog/is-icloud-keychain-safe">some drawbacks</a>. A major issue is that it doesn&#8217;t work well with other platforms, making it hard for Apple users to use their passwords and passkeys outside the Apple ecosystem.</p>



<p>Additionally, the company <a href="https://proton.me/blog/iphone-privacy">collects a lot of data</a> and has been accused of making <a href="https://appleinsider.com/articles/23/01/30/fourth-class-action-lawsuit-filed-against-apple-for-alleged-privacy-violations">misleading privacy claims</a>. Apple users concerned about their privacy might want to reconsider relying heavily on Apple products and explore privacy-focused alternatives to better protect their personal information.</p>



<p>This article shows how to find passwords on iPhone as well as how to delete them if you’re ready to switch to a privacy-first platform. Not ready to switch completely? We’ll show you how to improve your iCloud Keychain privacy and how easy it is to migrate your data.</p>



<ul>
<li><a href="#find">How to find saved passwords on iPhone</a></li>



<li><a href="#delete">How to delete saved passwords on iPhone</a></li>



<li><a href="#autofill">How to turn off password autofill on an iPhone</a></li>



<li><a href="#icloud-keychain">Does iCloud Keychain protect your passwords?</a></li>



<li><a href="#password-protection">How to improve your password protection on iPhone</a></li>



<li><a href="#proton-pass">Proton Pass keeps your data safe and private</a></li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="find">How to find saved passwords on iPhone&nbsp;</h2>



<p>There are three ways to locate passwords on your iPhone: using the Settings app, Spotlight Search, or Siri. Here’s how to use each:</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Using the Settings app</h3>



<ol>
<li>Open the <strong>Settings </strong>app on your iPhone.</li>



<li>Scroll down and, depending on your iOS version, tap <strong>Passwords </strong>(iOS 14 or later) or <strong>Passwords &amp; Accounts</strong> (iOS 13 or earlier).</li>



<li>Authenticate using Face ID, Touch ID, or your device passcode.</li>



<li>You will see a list of websites and apps, so you can tap one to view its saved passwords. You can also use the search bar at the top to quickly find the password you are looking for.</li>
</ol>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Using Spotlight Search</h3>



<ol>
<li>From the Home screen, swipe down from the middle of the screen to access Spotlight Search. Alternatively, you can swipe right on the Home screen until the Spotlight Search bar appears.</li>



<li>In the search bar, type <strong>Passwords</strong> to bring up the <strong>Passwords </strong>(iOS 14 or later) or <strong>Passwords &amp; Accounts</strong> (iOS 13 or earlier) section from the Settings app.</li>



<li>Follow the remaining steps above.</li>
</ol>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Using Siri</h3>



<ol>
<li>Activate Siri by saying &#8220;Hey Siri&#8221; if you have that feature enabled. Alternatively, press and hold the Home button (on an iPhone that has it) or the Side button (on an iPhone without a Home button).</li>



<li>Once Siri is activated, say something like &#8220;Show my passwords&#8221; or &#8220;Open my saved passwords&#8221;. You can also ask Siri to show a specific password by saying something like &#8220;Hey Siri, what&#8217;s my Netflix password?&#8221;</li>



<li>Siri will prompt you to authenticate using Face ID, Touch ID, or your device passcode.</li>



<li>After authentication, Siri will take you to the <strong>Passwords </strong>(iOS 14 or later) or <strong>Passwords &amp; Accounts</strong> (iOS 13 or earlier) section in the Settings app.</li>



<li>Follow the remaining steps from the Settings app section above.</li>
</ol>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="delete">How to delete saved passwords on iPhone</h2>



<p>Follow one of the methods above to reach the <strong>Passwords </strong>(iOS 14 or later) or <strong>Passwords &amp; Accounts</strong> (iOS 13 or earlier) section of your Settings app.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Individual passwords</h3>



<ol>
<li>Select a website or app.</li>



<li>Tap <strong>Delete Password</strong> at the bottom of the screen.</li>



<li>Confirm the deletion if prompted.</li>
</ol>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Multiple passwords at once</h3>



<ol>
<li>Tap <strong>Edit</strong> in the top-right corner of the screen.</li>



<li>Select the passwords you want to delete by tapping the circle next to each entry.</li>



<li>Tap <strong>Delete </strong>at the bottom of the screen.</li>



<li>Confirm the deletion if prompted.</li>
</ol>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="autofill">How to turn off password autofill on iPhone</h2>



<p>Even if you’ve deleted all your passwords, if you don’t turn off iCloud Keychain’s password autofill feature, it will continue to pop up as an option anytime you try to fill in a password field.&nbsp;</p>



<ol>
<li>Open the <strong>Settings </strong>app on your iPhone.</li>



<li>Scroll down and, depending on your iOS version, tap <strong>Passwords </strong>(iOS 14 or later) or <strong>Passwords &amp; Accounts</strong> (iOS 13 or earlier).</li>



<li>Authenticate using Face ID, Touch ID, or your device passcode.</li>



<li>Tap <strong>Password Options</strong>.</li>



<li>Tap the toggle switch next to <strong>iCloud Keychain</strong> to off.</li>
</ol>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="icloud-keychain">Does iCloud Keychain protect your passwords?</h2>



<p>The iCloud Keychain uses advanced encryption to protect your data, including <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-end-to-end-encryption">end-to-end encryption</a> so that no one can see your Keychain data, not even Apple. However, it has some limitations:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Privacy concerns</strong>: Although iCloud Keychain data is encrypted, <a href="https://proton.me/blog/apple-icloud-privacy">other iCloud data</a> (like Mail and Calendar) is not end-to-end encrypted by default, meaning Apple can access this information.</li>



<li><strong>Limited features</strong>: iCloud Keychain lacks several features found in other password managers, such as the ability to easily share passwords with anyone or store secure notes or custom entries.</li>



<li><strong>Device compatibility</strong>: iCloud Keychain works best within the Apple ecosystem. It does not integrate well with non-Apple devices like Android phones or Windows laptops.</li>



<li><strong>Passkey interoperability</strong>: <a href="https://proton.me/blog/big-tech-passkey">Apple&#8217;s passkeys</a> mostly work with its own products, making them difficult to use on non-Apple devices — <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-a-passkey">passkeys</a> become more secure and user-friendly as more devices use them. Plus, Apple passkeys can’t be shared or exported.</li>



<li><strong>Closed source</strong>: iCloud Keychain is not open-source, so independent security audits are not possible. You must trust Apple to identify and fix any security vulnerabilities.</li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="password-protection">How to improve your iPhone password protection</h2>



<p>Before implementing the steps below, make sure to follow basic <a href="https://protonvpn.com/blog/ultimate-guide-iphone-security">security practices for your iPhone</a>. For example, you should keep iOS updated, use Face ID or Touch ID, have a strong device passcode, regularly review app permissions, and only download apps from the App Store.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">1. Use strong, unique passwords</h3>



<p>Avoid using easily guessable passwords. Instead, your passwords should be at least 12 characters long, complex (a mix of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters), and unique.</p>



<p><a href="https://proton.me/pass">Proton Pass</a> can generate strong passwords for you and keep them in a safe place.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">2. Enable two-factor authentication</h3>



<p><a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-two-factor-authentication-2fa">Two-factor authentication (2FA)</a> adds an extra layer of security to your Apple ID. Even if someone guesses your password, they would still need to pass a second verification step to access your account.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">3. Enable Advanced Data Protection</h3>



<p><a href="https://support.apple.com/en-us/108756">Advanced Data Protection</a> is an Apple feature that is turned off by default. When enabled, it extends end-to-end encryption to more types of iCloud data, including backups, photos, and notes, beyond the apps that already have this protection by default. It can&#8217;t be enabled for managed Apple IDs or child accounts, though.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">4. Disable iCloud syncing</h3>



<p>If you don&#8217;t use specific Apple apps, such as Mail, Calendars, or Contacts, it&#8217;s safer to turn off iCloud syncing for these services since they can’t be protected with end-to-end encryption.&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="proton-pass">Proton Pass keeps your data safe and private</h2>



<p>Proton Pass is an encrypted password manager for <a href="https://proton.me/support/use-pass-ios">iOS</a> and other platforms that keeps all your passwords stored in a safe place. You can easily <a href="https://proton.me/support/pass-import-safari">import passwords from Safari</a>, generate strong passwords, <a href="https://protonvpn.com/support/ios-password-autofill/">autofill</a> them, and <a href="https://proton.me/support/pass-ios-share">safely share passwords</a> with anyone.</p>



<p>Our app supports <a href="https://proton.me/support/pass-use-passkeys#How-to-use-Proton-Pass-passkeys-on-iPhone">passkeys</a> on multiple platforms, which you can easily share or export. <p><a href="https://proton.me/pass/pass-monitor">Pass Monitor</a> is a feature that checks your account&#8217;s security. It uses Password Health to identify weak or reused passwords, and Dark Web Monitoring to check if your personal data is leaked online. Plus, <a href="https://proton.me/support/proton-sentinel">Proton Sentinel</a> provides advanced security against hackers.</p>



<p>We use <a href="https://proton.me/security/end-to-end-encryption">end-to-end encryption</a> to make sure no one can see your passwords and other personal information — not even us. All our apps are <a href="https://proton.me/community/open-source">open source</a> and audited by third parties. <p>Improve your iPhone password protection by <a href="https://proton.me/pass">signing up for a free Proton Pass account</a>.</p>

   <title>
    Proton Pass launches Secure Links for safe, convenient password sharing
   </title>
   <link/>
   https://proton.me/blog/pass-secure-link-sharing
   <guid ispermalink="true">
    https://proton.me/blog/pass-secure-link-sharing
   </guid>
   <description>
    Share passwords, bank details, and other sensitive data securely using unique, end-to-end encrypted links with anyone.
   </description>
   <pubdate>
    Fri, 12 Jul 2024 11:42:49 GMT
   </pubdate>
   <content:encoded>
    <p>There are many reasons you may need to share passwords, bank details, and other highly sensitive information. But we noticed that many people do this via messaging apps or other methods that put your data at risk.</p>



<p>In response to the needs of our community, we’re excited to announce that you now have a more secure and convenient way to share your items in your password manager with anyone, even if they don’t use Proton Pass.&nbsp;</p>



<p>With Secure Links, you can copy and paste unique, expirable links to your logins, bank cards, notes, and other items while preserving end-to-end encryption. Proton Pass makes securely sharing sensitive information simple and lets you manage your Secure Links from a central dashboard, ensuring you’re always in complete control of the items you’ve shared.</p>



<p>Starting today, we&#8217;ll begin rolling out Secure Links to everyone with a Proton Visionary or Lifetime plan. In the coming days, everyone with a paid Pass plan will be able to use Secure Links.</p>



<p>For a limited time, we’re helping more people take advantage of secure sharing and other advanced features by <strong>offering a year of Pass Plus for only $12</strong>. You not only get Secure Links but also unlimited vaults and <a href="https://proton.me/pass/aliases">hide-my-email aliases</a>, <a href="https://proton.me/pass/pass-monitor">Dark Web Monitoring</a>, our <a href="https://proton.me/blog/sentinel-included-pass-plus">Proton Sentinel</a> security program, integrated 2FA authenticator, and more. This offer ends July 21.&nbsp;</p>



<div class="text-center"><a class="btn inline-block rounded-full font-bold btn-small bg-purple-500 text-white hover:text-white focus:text-white" href="https://account.proton.me/pass/signup?&#038;coupon=SECURESHARING">Get the Pass Plus deal</a></div>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Why traditional password sharing is not secure</h2>



<p>It’s no secret that many people share passwords to streaming services and other subscription accounts. Family members also need to share other items like credit cards, ID numbers, and bank account logins. In the workplace, colleagues need access to shared WiFi passwords, social media accounts, and more.</p>



<p>Unfortunately, in most cases people share these sensitive items using methods that are inconvenient and not secure, such as text message or email. This makes it difficult to restrict access in the future, and whenever you update your password or other item details, you have to resend the information. Moreover, this increases the risk of <a href="https://proton.me/blog/how-to-prevent-data-breach">data breaches</a>, <a href="https://proton.me/blog/identity-theft-protection">identity theft</a>, or more <a href="https://protonvpn.com/blog/types-of-cyberattacks">sophisticated attacks</a>. Sharing passwords outside of Proton Pass in cleartext breaks end-to-end encryption.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Secure Links are easy to use and protect your data</h2>



<p>These unique, expirable links give you more flexibility and control over the items in your Proton Pass account without having to share sensitive information outside of Pass.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Importantly, you still have the ability to share items in your Proton Pass account using <a href="https://proton.me/support/pass-vault">vaults</a>. But Secure Links are designed to let you share single items more easily, including with people who don’t have a Pass account.</p>



<p>Here’s how Secure Link sharing works:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Easy as copy and paste: </strong>Sharing links is simple. You can generate, update, or delete Secure Links with a few clicks on any app.</li>



<li><strong>You’re in control:</strong> Set a date for the link to expire (anywhere from one hour up to 30 days) or restrict the number of times your recipient can access the link (from one to infinity). When you’re done sharing, just click the <strong>Remove link</strong> button in your dashboard.</li>



<li><strong>Encrypted at all times:</strong> Secure Links are end-to-end encrypted so only you and the people you share with can ever see your data. Not even Proton can access it: Secure Links are generated on your device, and when recipients open the link, the browser only sends the first part of the URL (before #decryptionkey) to the Proton servers. This means Proton never has access to the content of your Secure Link.</li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Better security without compromising convenience</h2>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img width="1024" height="573" data-public-id="wp-pme/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email.png" loading="lazy" decoding="async" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1024,h_573,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720554608/wp-pme/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email.png?_i=AA" alt="secure link sharing" class="wp-post-76227 wp-image-76236" data-format="png" data-transformations="f_auto,q_auto" data-version="1720554608" data-seo="1" srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1024,h_573,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720554608/wp-pme/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email.png?_i=AA 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_300,h_168,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720554608/wp-pme/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email.png?_i=AA 300w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_768,h_430,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720554608/wp-pme/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email.png?_i=AA 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/f_auto,q_auto/v1720554608/wp-pme/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email/pass-secure-link-extra-password-email.png?_i=AA 1072w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /></figure></div>


<p>Because Proton Pass is powered by our community rather than advertisers or venture investors, we are able to prioritize your security and privacy above everything else. And since we’re <a href="https://proton.me/foundation">owned by a nonprofit</a>, we’re only accountable to you and to our mission to expand global access to privacy.</p>



<p>To that end, in response to feedback from the community, <strong>we’re also launching an Extra Password feature</strong> alongside Secure Links. This optional feature lets you create a second password to access credentials stored in Pass for greater compartmentalization and peace of mind. Extra Password is available to the entire Proton Pass community, including those with Free plans.</p>



<p>You can turn on Extra Password now in your security settings. <a href="https://proton.me/support/pass-extra-password">Learn more.</a></p>



<p>With these new features, we aim to give you the best security possible without asking you to change the way you already use, share, and enjoy your password manager. We look forward to your feedback, which will directly shape the future of our products at Proton.</p>

   <title>
    How to build privacy-protecting AI
   </title>
   <link/>
   https://proton.me/blog/how-to-build-privacy-first-ai
   <guid ispermalink="true">
    https://proton.me/blog/how-to-build-privacy-first-ai
   </guid>
   <description>
    AI offers incredible productivity gains, often at the cost of privacy. Is it possible to build AI that protects privacy? We explain how it can be done.
   </description>
   <pubdate>
    Mon, 08 Jul 2024 14:14:28 GMT
   </pubdate>
   <content:encoded>
    <p>Large language models (LLMs) trained on public datasets can serve a wide range of purposes, from composing blog posts to programming. However, their true potential lies in contextualization, achieved by either fine-tuning the model or enriching its prompts with specific additional information. This process typically involves inputting custom data into the LLM, which might contain sensitive material such as personal messaging history, internal company documents, or workplace communications. The absence of robust privacy safeguards in these scenarios is one of the primary reasons why countries like<a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-65139406" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"> Italy have imposed bans</a> on platforms like ChatGPT.</p>



<p>LLMs are incredible tools, and we&#8217;ve only begun to scratch the surface of what they can do. However, like any tool, LLMs can be abused, particularly for surveillance. In this article, we show what we think the future of AI should look like, one where you can interact with LLMs and know the information you share is safe.</p>



<p>Currently, you have two options if you want to run an LLM:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Locally on your device: </strong>The LLM runs directly on your hardware using your browser and never interacts with external servers. This is the most private form of AI inference since your data never exits your machine, but it requires a machine with a powerful GPU due to the intensive calculations required by the LLM.</li>



<li><strong>Server side: </strong>Your requests are sent to external servers, which perform the LLM calculations using high-end GPUs. This AI instance has no specific hardware requirements and can be run on almost any smartphone, laptop, or desktop with internet connectivity. However, running requests on an external server increases data exposure risks unless the servers are secured and do not log your prompts or responses.</li>
</ol>



<p>This article looks at:</p>



<ul>
<li>The performance and openness of different LLMs, and explains which jobs each model is best suited to perform.</li>



<li>The technical challenges presented by <strong>on-device LLMs</strong> (for example, how to get them to run locally on your device).</li>



<li>How <strong>Server-side models </strong>work, and what can be done to enable more privacy-centric server-side processing.</li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Models</strong></h2>



<p>LLMs are trained on vast, diverse datasets sourced from the internet, including books, articles, and websites such as Wikipedia. This extensive data collection ensures the model learns the nuances of language, including syntax, semantics, and context.</p>



<p>The training process involves preprocessing the data through tokenization, normalization, and filtering to ensure quality and consistency. Using <a href="https://huggingface.co/learn/nlp-course/en/chapter1/4" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Transformer architecture</a>, the model learns by predicting the next word in a sentence and adjusting its internal parameters to minimize errors over millions or billions of examples. This computationally intensive process requires significant resources involving many powerful GPUs and days of training.</p>



<p>One advanced technique to refine LLMs is <a href="https://huggingface.co/blog/rlhf" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback</a> (RLHF). In this approach, human evaluators provide feedback on the model&#8217;s outputs, helping to fine-tune its responses. The feedback is used to train a reward model that predicts the quality of responses, and the LLM is further trained using reinforcement learning techniques guided by this reward model. RLHF ensures that the model&#8217;s outputs align more closely with human expectations, improving its usability in real-world applications.</p>



<p>When a model is trained, you can then perform <em>inference</em>, where the trained model generates predictions or responses based on new input data. This operation involves several steps, starting with a tokenized version of a user&#8217;s prompt. The model processes new input through its neural network layers to generate a coherent and contextually appropriate response. The model then converts the generated tokens back into human-readable text.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Model openness</strong></h3>



<p>One of the great success stories since the onset of ChatGPT has been the incredible work in creating open alternatives that anyone can use, thus democratizing LLMs.</p>



<p>However, whilst developers should be praised for their efforts, we should also be wary of &#8220;open washing&#8221;, akin to &#8220;privacy washing&#8221; or &#8220;greenwashing&#8221;, where companies say that their models are “open”, but actually only a small part is.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img width="1024" height="490" data-public-id="wp-pme/model-openness-2/model-openness-2.png" loading="lazy" decoding="async" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1024,h_490,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720442390/wp-pme/model-openness-2/model-openness-2.png?_i=AA" alt="" class="wp-post-76176 wp-image-76209" data-format="png" data-transformations="f_auto,q_auto" data-version="1720442390" data-seo="1" srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1024,h_490,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720442390/wp-pme/model-openness-2/model-openness-2.png?_i=AA 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_300,h_143,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720442390/wp-pme/model-openness-2/model-openness-2.png?_i=AA 300w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_768,h_367,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720442390/wp-pme/model-openness-2/model-openness-2.png?_i=AA 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1536,h_735,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720442390/wp-pme/model-openness-2/model-openness-2.png?_i=AA 1536w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1568,h_750,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720442390/wp-pme/model-openness-2/model-openness-2.png?_i=AA 1568w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/f_auto,q_auto/v1720442390/wp-pme/model-openness-2/model-openness-2.png?_i=AA 1723w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">A subset of the most popular models and their openness shows that there are many scales of openness, from OLMo at the top (by AllenAI) down to ChatGPT, which is the worst. Source: <a href="https://opening-up-chatgpt.github.io/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">https://opening-up-chatgpt.github.io/</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Open LLMs like <a href="https://huggingface.co/allenai/OLMo-7B-Instruct" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">OLMo 7B Instruct</a> provide significant advantages in benchmarking, reproducibility, algorithmic transparency, bias detection, and community collaboration. They allow for rigorous performance evaluation and validation of AI research, which in turn promotes trust and enables the community to identify and address biases. Collaborative efforts lead to shared improvements and innovations, accelerating advancements in AI. Additionally, open LLMs offer flexibility for tailored solutions and experimentation, allowing users to customize and explore novel applications and methodologies.</p>



<p>By democratizing access to advanced AI, open LLMs help prevent the concentration of AI capabilities within a few dominant tech companies, promoting a more balanced distribution of power.</p>



<p>Conversely, Meta or OpenAI, for example, have a very different definition of “open” to <a href="https://allenai.org/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">AllenAI</a> (the institute behind OLMo 7B Instruct). These companies have made their code, data, weights, and research papers only partially available or haven’t shared them&nbsp; at all.</p>



<p>Openness in LLMs is crucial for privacy and ethical data use, as it allows people to verify what data the model utilized and if this data was sourced responsibly. By making LLMs open, the community can scrutinize and verify the datasets, guaranteeing that personal information is protected and that data collection practices adhere to ethical standards. This transparency fosters trust and accountability, essential for developing AI technologies that respect user privacy and uphold ethical principles.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Model size and performance</strong></h3>



<h4 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Large models</strong></h4>



<p>So far, size matters when it comes to LLMs — bigger models perform better than smaller models for the following reasons:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Capacity to learn complex patterns</strong>: With more parameters (over 70 billion for Llama3), larger models can learn and represent more complex patterns in the data. This allows them to generate more accurate and nuanced responses.</li>



<li><strong>Better generalization</strong>: Larger models can generalize better from training data to unseen data. They can capture a broader range of linguistic structures and nuances, leading to improved performance across various tasks.</li>



<li><strong>Higher contextual understanding</strong>: Larger models can maintain and process longer contexts, enabling them to generate more coherent and contextually appropriate responses. This is particularly important for tasks that require an understanding of extended text, such as summarization and dialogue generation.</li>



<li><strong>Improved fine-tuning</strong>: Larger models provide a better foundation for fine-tuning on specific tasks or domains. They can leverage their extensive pre-trained knowledge to adapt more effectively to specialized datasets, enhancing performance in specific applications.</li>
</ul>



<p>Large models, with their large number of parameters (and therefore weights), take up a lot of memory and require considerable CPU or GPU resources to perform inference effectively. So even if GPT4 was open, running it would still be prohibitively expensive.</p>



<p>There are, however, some ways to make large models smaller without dramatically sacrificing performance, including:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Model quantization: </strong>This is when large, memory-hungry, floating-point representations of model weights are converted to 8-bit or 4-bit representations, allowing LLMs to use lower-precision arithmetic. This significantly reduces the device&#8217;s memory and computational requirements without greatly sacrificing the model&#8217;s accuracy.<br>&#8220;Quantization and Training of Neural Networks for Efficient Integer-Arithmetic-Only Inference&#8221; by Jacob et al., 2018.“ Llm. int8: 8-bit matrix multiplication for transformers at scale” by Dettmers et al., 2022.</li>



<li><strong>Weight pruning: </strong>This involves removing less significant weights from the model, reducing its size and computational demands while maintaining accuracy.<br>&#8220;Learning both Weights and Connections for Efficient Neural Networks&#8221; by Han et al., 2015.</li>
</ul>



<p>Then, finally, there is the option for smaller, more specialized, less resource-intensive models.</p>



<h4 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Smaller models</strong></h4>



<p>With a smaller number of parameters, smaller models also require fewer calculations at inference time, making them faster and less resource intensive in terms of memory and GPU usage, opening the door to running LLMs directly on a consumer device.&nbsp;</p>



<p>While smaller models typically don’t perform as well as larger models on a general basis due to their inability to capture more nuanced patterns in text, there are several ways we can make smaller models behave more like larger ones for specific tasks. These include:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Knowledge distillation: </strong>This is when a large, pre-trained model (teacher) is used to train a smaller model (student) that mimics the performance of the larger model but with fewer parameters, making it more suitable for on-device execution.<br>&#8220;Distilling the Knowledge in a Neural Network&#8221; by Hinton, Vinyals, and Dean, 2015.&#8221;DistilBERT, a distilled version of BERT: smaller, faster, cheaper and lighter&#8221; by Sanh et al., 2019.</li>



<li><strong>Mixture of Experts</strong> (<strong>MoE</strong>): MoE models, like Mixtral 8x7B, enhance performance by combining multiple specialized, smaller models (experts), each focusing on different aspects of the input data (for example, one model for punctuation, one for verbs, another form numbers, etc.). A gating mechanism dynamically selects the most relevant experts for each input, ensuring only a subset is activated, reducing computational costs and improving efficiency. This approach allows MoE models to specialize and scale effectively while providing high accuracy and robustness across diverse tasks without proportional increases in computational demands.</li>
</ul>



<p>Models like Mixtral 8x7B Instruct outperform models like Llama2, with its 70 billion parameters, in terms of their ability to generate coherent content, but are also six times faster to perform inference on.<br><br>For very large models, Mixtral 8x22B models can perform on par or even better than GPT4 and GPT3.5. Given that GPT4 uses a reported 1.76 trillion parameters, it’s impressive that a model with an order of magnitude fewer parameters can perform similarly.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>On-device LLMs</strong></h2>



<p>The open nature of models and subsequent developments by researchers and engineers have led to LLMs that can run on a user device without a dramatic dip in accuracy or speed.&nbsp;</p>



<p>On-device LLMs can deliver powerful AI capabilities while preserving user privacy and thus work within E2EE settings. A few open-source projects, most notably <a href="https://github.com/ggerganov/llama.cpp" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Llamacpp</a> and <a href="https://webllm.mlc.ai/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">WebLLM</a>, make it easier to run LLMs locally.</p>



<p><a href="https://github.com/ggerganov/llama.cpp" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Llamacpp</a> is an open-source C++ library that allows you to run your own OpenAI-compatible API on top of an LLM on your machine (or server) utilizing CPUs or GPUs. One of the key optimization techniques used in llama.cpp is quantization, which significantly reduces the memory footprint and speeds up inference without large sacrifices on accuracy.</p>



<p>Llamacpp requires models to be loaded from the GPT-Generated Unified Format (GGUF), a custom binary format that efficiently stores machine-learning model parameters. It’s designed to optimize the storage and access of model weights, particularly for scenarios where models need to be loaded quickly and used in memory-constrained environments.</p>



<p>The <a href="https://webllm.mlc.ai/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">WebLLM</a> project allows you to run LLMs directly in your web browser. WebLLM leverages the power of <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/webgpu/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">WebGPU</a> and the optimization prowess of <a href="https://tvm.apache.org/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Apache TVM</a>.</p>



<p>Apache TVM is an open-source machine learning compiler that plays a crucial role in making WebLLM possible using:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Model transformation</strong>: Models crafted in high-level frameworks like TensorFlow or PyTorch are imported into TVM. TVM then converts these models into an intermediate representation (IR) that can be fine-tuned for performance.</li>



<li><strong>Optimization</strong>: TVM performs a series of sophisticated optimizations on this IR. It fuses operations to reduce redundant memory access, plans memory usage efficiently, and restructures computation graphs for maximum parallelism. This step is key to making models run fast and lean on your browser’s GPU.</li>



<li><strong>Code Generation</strong>: Once optimized, TVM generates code tailored for WebGPU. This involves compiling kernels and creating runtime code that can execute efficiently on the GPU.</li>
</ol>



<p>WebGPU is a modern graphics API designed to give web applications direct access to GPU power. For WebLLM, WebGPU is the engine that runs the finely tuned code generated by Apache TVM. Here’s how it fits into the picture:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Resource management</strong>: WebGPU handles the allocation and management of GPU memory for model parameters, input data, and computations, ensuring the efficient use of resources.</li>
</ul>



<ul>
<li><strong>Shader execution</strong>: It compiles and runs shaders — small programs on the GPU — that carry out the heavy lifting of neural network operations.</li>



<li><strong>Command Handling</strong>: WebGPU encodes and submits commands to the GPU, orchestrating the execution of the optimized code and ensuring smooth operation.</li>
</ul>



<p>At this moment, <a href="https://caniuse.com/webgpu" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">WebGPU support</a> isn’t present across all browsers, at least not by default. Safari, for example, has only recently added support in its &#8220;Technology Preview&#8221; version, and Firefox makes you enable a flag called dom.webgpu.enabled. Practically no mobile browsers, apart from Chromium-based ones, support WebGPU. These caveats make it difficult to support all users by default.</p>



<p>There are also other considerations besides the lack of WebGPU support that make in-browser models difficult to run. To run a model locally, you must have:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Sufficient bandwidth:</strong> You must download a multi-GB model (again, larger models will typically yield better results).</li>



<li><strong>A reasonably powerful GPU:</strong> If you have a Mac, any Apple M series machine can run a 7B parameter model. If you use Windows or Linux, a dedicated GPU with 6 GB VRAM will run an LLM.</li>
</ul>



<p>As you can see, it’s already possible to run a personalized LLM with secure access to your personalized data on your computer or smartphone — as long as your device is powerful enough. Unfortunately, this requirement prices out many people. Most models are also prohibitively large, making it difficult to download them in remote locations or in countries with poor internet infrastructure.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>The future of on-device</strong></h3>



<p>While the ability to run on-device LLMs is currently limited to the best, most powerful, and most expensive devices, we’ve already seen remarkable technological progress over the past two years towards making LLMs available to everyone. The trends we see today will likely continue to move towards:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Local by default: </strong>LLMs are expensive to run, so off-loading generation to the client makes sense both from a privacy and cost perspective. More support for WebGPU will make it easier for <em>all users</em> to run models in their browsers.</li>



<li><strong>Smaller LLMs: </strong>task-specific LLMs will become more common, allowing you to switch between models as you switch between tasks — for example, one for email, one for document creation, one for image, audio, search, and so on. Smaller models run faster and are already shown to perform as well as, and, <a href="https://huggingface.co/defog/sqlcoder-7b-2" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">in some cases, better than</a> large models such as GPT 4 on specific tasks.</li>



<li><strong>LLMs within SDKs/browsers: </strong>Application developers will soon be able to call LLMs much like they call other features in an SDK, such as getting access to the user&#8217;s camera in an Android application. This will make LLM integration easier and, if handled on-device, private by default as well.</li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Server-side LLMs</strong></h2>



<p>Server-side models remain the fastest and most reliable method for running LLMs, ensuring robust performance and stability.</p>



<p>Running LLMs on your own machine enhances your privacy but requires powerful hardware to effectively manage the computational demands.</p>



<p>We have already seen how LlamaCPP can be used to run models on consumer devices, but it can also be used on servers, providing the interfaces to run models performantly on high-end GPUs. It has support for the functionalities required to run LLMs in more production-level environments with parallelism (to serve multiple users at the same time), access tokens (to provide server access only to those with permission), SSL (to encrypt traffic from a client to server), and health monitoring (to ensure your system is alive).</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Server-side models</strong></h3>



<p>While the models mentioned earlier for on-device can also work server side, it typically makes sense to run more powerful models to get better performance (should you need it). Looking at the graph below, you will see how Mixtral 8x22B models compare with GPT 4 Turbo or GPT 3.5 Turbo. If you want ChatGPT-level model performance, you can already get very close to it.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img width="1024" height="617" data-public-id="wp-pme/server-side-performance2x/server-side-performance2x.png" loading="lazy" decoding="async" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1024,h_617,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425818/wp-pme/server-side-performance2x/server-side-performance2x.png?_i=AA" alt="" class="wp-post-76176 wp-image-76197" data-format="png" data-transformations="f_auto,q_auto" data-version="1720425818" data-seo="1" srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1024,h_617,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425818/wp-pme/server-side-performance2x/server-side-performance2x.png?_i=AA 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_300,h_181,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425818/wp-pme/server-side-performance2x/server-side-performance2x.png?_i=AA 300w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_768,h_463,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425818/wp-pme/server-side-performance2x/server-side-performance2x.png?_i=AA 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1536,h_926,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425818/wp-pme/server-side-performance2x/server-side-performance2x.png?_i=AA 1536w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1568,h_946,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425818/wp-pme/server-side-performance2x/server-side-performance2x.png?_i=AA 1568w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425818/wp-pme/server-side-performance2x/server-side-performance2x.png?_i=AA 1723w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Server-side model performance for text summarization and composition performed by Apple, adapted from <a href="https://machinelearning.apple.com/research/introducing-apple-foundation-models" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">https://machinelearning.apple.com/research/introducing-apple-foundation-models</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>However, as stated before, it’s debatable whether you need ChatGPT-level performance for most tasks. Using one large model for all tasks is wasteful, like hiring a gourmet chef to boil potatoes. The chef will do it, but you&#8217;ll pay a hefty price for the privilege. Just because you <em>can</em> doesn’t mean you should.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>The future of server-side inference</strong></h3>



<p>Homomorphic encryption (HE) is a promising, albeit still developing, approach to enable privacy-preserving inference on LLMs across networks.</p>



<p>HE is important because it offers a powerful way to work with encrypted data. It allows computations to be performed on ciphertexts that, when decrypted, yield the same result as if the operations had been performed on the plaintext. This characteristic makes HE particularly intriguing for applications involving sensitive data, including working with LLMs.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img width="1024" height="617" data-public-id="wp-pme/gpt-architecture-fhe-1/gpt-architecture-fhe-1.png" loading="lazy" decoding="async" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1024,h_617,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425828/wp-pme/gpt-architecture-fhe-1/gpt-architecture-fhe-1.png?_i=AA" alt="" class="wp-post-76176 wp-image-76193" data-format="png" data-transformations="f_auto,q_auto" data-version="1720425828" data-seo="1" srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1024,h_617,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425828/wp-pme/gpt-architecture-fhe-1/gpt-architecture-fhe-1.png?_i=AA 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_300,h_181,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425828/wp-pme/gpt-architecture-fhe-1/gpt-architecture-fhe-1.png?_i=AA 300w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_768,h_463,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425828/wp-pme/gpt-architecture-fhe-1/gpt-architecture-fhe-1.png?_i=AA 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1536,h_925,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425828/wp-pme/gpt-architecture-fhe-1/gpt-architecture-fhe-1.png?_i=AA 1536w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1568,h_945,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425828/wp-pme/gpt-architecture-fhe-1/gpt-architecture-fhe-1.png?_i=AA 1568w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/f_auto,q_auto/v1720425828/wp-pme/gpt-architecture-fhe-1/gpt-architecture-fhe-1.png?_i=AA 1723w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">GPT2 with fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) replicates the overall GPT2 architecture, but with the difference that the client performs part of the work and the server performs the computationally heavy, self-attention operations in an FHE way. Adapted from <a href="https://huggingface.co/blog/encrypted-llm" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">https://huggingface.co/blog/encrypted-llm</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Homomorphic computing is a method of performing computations on encrypted data without needing to decrypt it first. This approach preserves privacy and security throughout the computational process. Here&#8217;s how it can be applied to perform inference on a LLM:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Encryption:</strong> User input (for example, text) is encrypted using a homomorphic encryption scheme. This ensures that the input data remains confidential and secure.</li>



<li><strong>Computation: </strong>The LLM, which has been adapted to support homomorphic operations,&nbsp; processes the encrypted input. The model performs its calculations directly on the encrypted data, generating an encrypted output.</li>



<li><strong>Decryption:</strong> The encrypted result produced by the LLM is then decrypted to provide the final plaintext output to the user.</li>
</ul>



<p>While homomorphic encryption already exists, it&#8217;s still in its early stages and can&#8217;t yet scale to handle LLMs for a number of reasons:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Performance</strong>: Homomorphic encryption is computationally intensive and can significantly slow down the inference process. Advances in hardware and optimization techniques are needed to make this approach practical for real-time applications.</li>



<li><strong>Model adaptation</strong>: Existing LLMs need to be adapted to support homomorphic operations, which can be complex and require specialized knowledge in both cryptography and machine learning.</li>



<li><strong>Scalability</strong>: Ensuring that the homomorphic encryption scheme can scale to handle large models and large volumes of data is crucial for widespread adoption.</li>
</ul>



<p><a href="https://www.zama.ai/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Zama</a>, for example, is trying to build fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) into ML algorithms and has a <a href="https://huggingface.co/blog/encrypted-llm" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">functional example</a> of how to do this with GPT-2 models, although slowly (and expensively). However, as <a href="https://www.zama.ai/post/chatgpt-privacy-with-homomorphic-encryption" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Zama explains</a>, there is a path forward to FHE LLMs in the next few years through further LLM compression, improvements to the cryptography behind FHE, and dedicated hardware acceleration predicted to arrive in 2025.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Privacy is the future of AI</strong></h2>



<p>Generative AI is potentially a generation-defining development — one that&#8217;s on the mind of the Proton community, as was made evident in our <a href="https://proton.me/blog/2024-proton-survey-results">2024 survey</a>. Recent technological developments have made LLMs more open, smaller, and faster, opening entirely new possibilities for GenAI.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Today, many people can already run a personalized, fully private AI assistant on their device by combining these LLMs with your own content — something that was only possible in the realm of science fiction a handful of years ago.</p>



<p>The next frontier is bringing this level of performance to people with connectivity or device limitations. FHE seems like it could bridge this gap, allowing for encrypted, privacy-respecting LLMs in the not-so-distant future. Until then, server-side models running on high-performance GPUs will remain the fastest way to generate content under these adverse conditions, but at the possible cost of some levels of privacy.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

   <title>
    Is Google Docs secure and does it respect your privacy?
   </title>
   <link/>
