   <description>
    We’re looking into Google Docs' security risks to see how your data might be exposed and ways to protect it.
   </description>
   <pubdate>
    Fri, 05 Jul 2024 10:52:56 GMT
   </pubdate>
   <content:encoded>
    <p>Your <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-your-data-worth" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">online data is incredibly valuable</a>, particularly to companies like Google that use it to make money through ads. This, along with <a href="https://proton.me/blog/google-privacy-washing" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Google’s numerous privacy violations</a>, has led many to question the safety of their information and find <a href="https://proton.me/blog/how-to-de-google" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">alternatives to Google</a>.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Google Docs has <a href="https://marketsplash.com/google-workspace-statistics/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">over 1 billion</a> active monthly users, making it one of the most popular productivity tools, especially as more people work from home. But there are many reasons that Google Docs may not be the most secure or private home for your data. Google does not use end-to-end encryption, meaning the company has access to your data, which could be exposed in a data breach.</p>



<p>This article examines the security of Google Docs and the many concerning privacy issues. We also offer tips to improve your Google Docs security and alternatives to try instead.</p>



<p>Or skip to the following sections:</p>



<ul>
<li><a href="#what-makes-Google-Docs-so-popular">What makes Google Docs so popular?</a></li>



<li><a href="#Does-Google-Docs-protect-your-privacy">How secure are Google Docs?</a></li>



<li><a href="#Does Google Docs protect your privacy">Does Google Docs protect your privacy?</a></li>



<li><a href="#How-to-increase-your-Google-Docs-security">How to increase your Google Docs security</a></li>



<li><a href="#Secure-your-data-with-Proton-Drive">Secure your data with Proton Docs</a></li>



<li><a href="#proton-defends-you">How Proton defends you</a></li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="What-makes-Google-Docs-so-popular">What makes Google Docs so popular?</h2>



<p>Google Docs is a web-based application that allows users to create, edit, and store documents in the cloud. Its key features include real-time collaboration, automatic saving, and easy sharing options.</p>



<p>You can access your documents from any device with an internet connection, view version history to track and roll back content changes, suggest changes to a file for reviews, and work on documents offline. Google Docs is flexible and accessible, especially since it&#8217;s free. But “free” just means you <a href="https://proton.me/blog/ad-free-business-model" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">pay in other ways</a>.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="How-secure-are-Google-Docs">How secure are Google docs?</h2>



<p>Google hasn&#8217;t experienced any publicly reported data breaches since 2018, when a bug in the Google+ API <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/google-plus-bug-52-million-users-data-exposed/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">exposed the private data</a> of over 50 million users. However, its security features aren’t airtight.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Encryption</h3>



<p>Google Docs uses <a href="https://protonvpn.com/blog/what-is-aes-encryption/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">AES-256 encryption</a> to secure your data in transit, at rest, on Google&#8217;s servers, and during backups. Any information being transferred between the user’s device and Google’s servers is <a href="https://cloud.google.com/docs/security/encryption/default-encryption" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">encrypted</a>.</p>



<p>If a hacker gets their hands on your data in transit, they wouldn&#8217;t be able to read it due to encryption. However, Google can see everything you do since it doesn’t use <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-end-to-end-encryption" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">end-to-end encryption</a>, so your data is more vulnerable to data breaches affecting Google’s servers.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Account security</h3>



<p>Google accounts support <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-two-factor-authentication-2fa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">two-factor authentication (2FA)</a> and <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-a-passkey" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">passkeys</a>, making unauthorized access more difficult. 2FA <a href="https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/185839" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">adds a second form of verification</a>, like sending a code on an authenticator, while passkeys let you sign in to your Google account with your fingerprint, face scan, or device screen lock, like a PIN.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Access controls</h3>



<p>By default, your Google Drive documents are set to private. As an owner, you can configure permission settings and select who can view, comment on, or edit your documents, such as individual users, groups, or anyone by creating shareable links. It&#8217;s also possible to see who has accessed documents and what changes have been made, as well as to set expiration dates if you have a school or work account.&nbsp;</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Malware protection</h3>



<p>Google automatically processes your content to provide spam filtering, virus detection, and malware protection. If any document is suspicious, Google shows a warning in Drive, including others you may have shared the file with, and it also notifies you via email.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="Does-Google-Docs-protect-your-privacy">Does Google Docs protect your privacy?</h2>



<p><strong>Google often uses </strong><a href="https://proton.me/blog/google-privacy-washing" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><strong>misleading privacy claims</strong></a> and prefers to settle lawsuits totaling billions of dollars rather than face in-depth scrutiny.&nbsp;</p>



<p>For example, Google settled a $93 million lawsuit in 2023, when it <a href="https://www.reuters.com/legal/google-reaches-93-million-privacy-settlement-with-california-2023-09-14/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">deceived</a> users by continuing to track their location data even after they had turned off the location history setting on their devices. In 2020, Google faced a $5 billion class-action lawsuit for collecting user data when using the <a href="https://proton.me/blog/google-incognito-lawsuit" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Google Chrome incognito browsing mode</a>, which it also settled.</p>



<p>Considering the company’s track record on privacy, it’s helpful to investigate how Google collects and uses the contents of your files in Google Docs.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Data collection</h3>



<p>According to its <a href="https://policies.google.com/privacy" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">privacy policy</a>, Google collects the content you create, upload, or share with others — including everything in your Google documents.</p>



<p>Google specifically <a href="https://support.google.com/docs/answer/10381817?hl=en" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">processes your content in Google Docs</a> to search for spam and malware, and so that you can search your documents. And every time you search, Google also saves your queries. The company can combine this data with other information it collects, such as your location, name, and phone number.&nbsp;</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Advertising</h3>



<p>Google doesn&#8217;t use the content you store in Google Docs for advertising. <a href="https://support.google.com/docs/answer/10381817" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">According</a> to the company, it doesn’t share your <a href="https://proton.me/blog/personal-data" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">personally identifiable information</a> with advertisers unless you ask them to, like selecting the call button to call a shop straight from your browser.&nbsp;</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">AI training</h3>



<p>There’s nothing in Google’s <a href="https://policies.google.com/privacy" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">privacy policy</a> that prevents the company from using the content you create, upload, or receive (including Google Docs) and publicly available information to train their AI models. If you want to be absolutely certain your data isn’t being ingested into Google’s training models, the only solution would be to stop using Google services.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Third-party access</h3>



<p>As with any other app, integrating Google Docs with third-party add-ons raises concerns since their privacy policies may differ from Google&#8217;s. For instance, a third-party add-on could see your personal information and use it for analytics or to show ads. It may also <a href="https://support.google.com/marketplace/answer/180490" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">expose your data to third parties</a>.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="How-to-increase-your-Google-Docs-security">How to increase your Google Docs security</h2>



<p>Most security issues happen because users are not careful enough with their Google accounts, like <strong>failing to sign out when using a shared computer</strong>. Check out the following tips to stay safe when using Google Docs:</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">1. Secure your Google account</h3>



<p>Protect your Google account with a <a href="https://proton.me/blog/create-remember-strong-passwords" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">strong password</a> to prevent hackers from decrypting it in a data breach. You should also enable <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-two-factor-authentication-2fa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">two-factor authentication (2FA)</a> to add another layer of defense in case someone learns your password. Setting up a <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-a-passkey">passkey</a> offers even better security.</p>



<p><a href="https://proton.me/pass">Proton Pass</a> is a secure password manager that offers a <a href="https://proton.me/pass/password-generator" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">random password generator</a>, <a href="https://proton.me/support/pass-2fa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">authenticator for 2FA</a>, and support for <a href="https://proton.me/support/pass-use-passkeys" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">passkeys</a>, so you can use it to enhance the protection of your Google account.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">2. Be mindful of your Google account</h3>



<p>Google has been known to <a href="https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/40695" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">disable accounts</a> for perceived violations of its <a href="https://policies.google.com/terms" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">terms of service</a> for Docs or any other Google product. So, for example, if you break a rule on YouTube, you might also lose access to your documents, emails, or any other Google service. Sometimes the company’s automated systems can <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/21/technology/google-surveillance-toddler-photo.html" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">wrongly flag</a> you.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">3. Control who can access your documents</h3>



<p>Avoid sharing documents using the “Anyone on the internet” setting unless you are comfortable with them becoming publicly available information. When sharing documents, use restricted sharing options for specific people rather than broad access levels. Additionally, you can check the activity dashboard to see who has accessed your documents and when.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">4. Check the permissions of third-party add-ons</h3>



<p>Before installing a third-party add-on from Google Marketplace, check the Permissions tab to see what data it collects and how it processes it. You can also look over its privacy policy and check if the app is independently audited.&nbsp;</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">5. Encrypt your documents</h3>



<p><a href="https://support.google.com/docs/answer/10519333" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Google work or school accounts</a> can create new encrypted documents and encrypt documents before uploading them if the admin enabled client-side encryption. It&#8217;s also possible to collaborate on encrypted docs. However, free Google accounts can&#8217;t use this encryption feature. It’s far easier to use a service that stores documents using end-to-end encryption by default, such as <a href="https://proton.me/drive">Proton Drive</a>.&nbsp;</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">6. Back up your important documents</h3>



<p>In 2023, many people <a href="https://support.google.com/drive/thread/245055606/google-drive-files-suddenly-disappeared-the-drive-literally-went-back-to-condition-in-may-2023" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">reported</a> significant data losses with Google Drive, which underscores the need to <a href="https://proton.me/blog/how-to-back-up-files" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">back up important files</a>. Fortunately, the company makes it easy to <a href="https://takeout.google.com/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">download your Google data</a> and back it up or move it to another cloud storage service.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="Secure-your-data-with-Proton-Drive">Secure your data with Proton Docs</h2>



<p>Proton has now launched Proton Docs, a secure end-to-end encrypted fully-featured Google Docs alternative that respects your privacy. </p>

<p>If you already have Proton Drive and want to experience Proton Docs, just log in to <a href="https://docs.proton.me">docs.proton.me</a> using your Proton Account username and password (plus 2FA, if configured) and select <strong>+</strong> <strong>New</strong> → <strong>New document</strong>. </p>



<p>Proton Drive is a safer alternative to Google Drive for cloud storage and collaboration since we use <a href="https://proton.me/security/end-to-end-encryption" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">end-to-end encryption</a> to ensure no one can see your private data — not even us. All files are automatically encrypted before upload.</p>



<p>Proton Drive lets you <a href="https://proton.me/drive/file-sharing" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">securely share files</a> and with anyone, even non-Proton users. You can set expiration dates for shared files, allow viewing or editing, protect links with passwords, easily <a href="https://proton.me/support/drive-how-to-share-files-via-email" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">share files via email</a>, and track how many times your files were downloaded.</p>

<p>Moving away from Google means finding a provider you can trust with your data, so you won&#8217;t have to worry about privacy violations. Millions of people worldwide trust Proton with their internet privacy, including journalists and activists.</p>



<p>Unlike Google, Proton doesn&#8217;t use your data to make money — we are exclusively funded by our community of subscribers and primarily <a href="https://proton.me/blog/proton-non-profit-foundation" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">owned by a nonprofit</a> focused on promoting online privacy for all. Additionally, we operate under <a href="https://proton.me/blog/switzerland" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">strong Swiss privacy laws</a>. All our apps are <a href="https://proton.me/community/open-source" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">open source</a> and independently audited.</p>



<p>Signing up for a Proton account means gaining access to an encrypted ecosystem designed to protect all your data, including <a href="https://proton.me/drive">cloud storage</a>, <a href="https://proton.me/pass">passwords</a>, <a href="https://protonvpn.com/?ref=prdmenuvpn">internet connection</a>, <a href="https://proton.me/mail">email</a>, and <a href="https://proton.me/calendar">calendar</a>.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Frequently asked questions</h2>



<div class="schema-faq wp-block-yoast-faq-block"><div class="schema-faq-section" id="faq-question-1719386555643"><strong class="schema-faq-question">How to make Google Docs secure?</strong> <p class="schema-faq-answer">You can improve your privacy and security when using Google Docs by using strong passwords and 2FA or passkeys for your Google account. You should also manage who can access your documents, check the permissions of third-party add-ons, and encrypt your documents before uploading them to Google Drive.</p> </div> <div class="schema-faq-section" id="faq-question-1719386563275"><strong class="schema-faq-question">What are three disadvantages of Google Docs?</strong> <p class="schema-faq-answer">The biggest concern with Google Docs is that Google can see your documents since it doesn&#8217;t use end-to-end encryption. You could also lose access to your account if Google suspects you broke its terms of service, which means losing important documents if you haven&#8217;t backed them up elsewhere. Additionally, nothing in Google&#8217;s policies prevents them from freely using your documents to train AI models without your consent.</p> </div> <div class="schema-faq-section" id="faq-question-1719386572308"><strong class="schema-faq-question">Is it safe to keep passwords in Google Docs?</strong> <p class="schema-faq-answer">Google doesn&#8217;t use end-to-end encryption, so the company and its employees can see your passwords. If you use third-party add-ons with Google Drive, those may see your passwords, too. Additionally, Google can disable your account if it thinks you violated its terms of service when using any of its products.     <p>Billions of people use online document editors like Google Docs or Microsoft 365 to write reports, collaborate on projects, and keep track of meeting notes. But there is a growing concern about Big Tech platforms having access to your content, tracking you across the web, and collecting data to train privacy-invading AI models.</p>



<p>Today we’re announcing <strong>a new end-to-end encrypted, collaborative document editor</strong> that puts your privacy first. Docs in Proton Drive are built on the same privacy and security principles as all our services, starting with end-to-end encryption. Docs let you collaborate in real time, leave comments, add photos, and store your files securely. Best of all, it’s all private — even keystrokes and cursor movements are encrypted.</p>



<p>Get started by <a href="https://account.proton.me/drive/signup">creating a free Proton Drive account today</a> (if you don’t already have one). We are rolling out Docs starting today, and the feature will be available to all users over the next couple of days. At that time, if you go to <a href="http://drive.proton.me/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">drive.proton.me</a> and click on <em>New</em> in the top left, you will see the ability to create a New document.</p>

<div class="text-center"><a class="btn inline-block rounded-full font-bold btn-small btn-solid-purple" href="https://account.proton.me/drive/signup">Get Proton Drive</a></div>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Why we’re launching a privacy-first document editor</h2>



<p>Online document editors have become a core productivity tool, used for everything from private journals to sensitive business strategies. The problem is that most companies offering document editors today are the same Big Tech companies that collect and monetize your private information.</p>



<p>As a result, there are multiple significant issues:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Mass data collection</strong>— Document editors such as Google Docs can see everything you write and keep a record of all changes that you have ever made. Once you provide your data to these companies, you no longer have control over how it is used. <strong>Data that you think is private may even be used to train AI in the future</strong>.</li>



<li><strong>Risk of data breaches</strong> — No major document editor protects your data with <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-end-to-end-encryption" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">end-to-end encryption</a> by default, which leaves your documents vulnerable to hackers and data breaches. When companies can decrypt your data, it’s like leaving the key next to the safe.</li>



<li><strong>Weak privacy laws</strong> —&nbsp;Tech companies with headquarters and data centers in the US are subject to bulk surveillance and lax data protection laws.</li>



<li><strong>Third-party and government access</strong> —&nbsp;Without end-to-end encryption or strong legal protections, your documents are subject to <a href="https://proton.me/blog/us-warrantless-surveillance" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">warrantless surveillance</a> and <a href="https://policies.google.com/privacy?hl=en-US#infosharing" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">data sharing</a>.</li>
</ul>



<p>When you write in a document, you would like to think your ideas are only for you and the people you choose to share with. But that’s not really the case.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Bringing Proton privacy to collaborative online documents</h2>



<p>We built docs in Proton Drive as a joint project <a href="https://proton.me/blog/proton-standard-notes-join-forces" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">with the team from Standard Notes</a>, who share our core values around privacy and security.&nbsp;</p>



<p>As with all Proton services, Docs put you back in control of your data. Thanks to our open-source end-to-end encryption, you are the only one with the key to read and share your documents. Not even Proton can access your docs content or metadata (such as file names). Instead of storing your data in the US, where it can be subject to government surveillance, Proton is protected by <a href="https://proton.me/blog/switzerland" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">strict Swiss privacy laws</a>.</p>



<p>Docs are integrated into your Proton Drive, meaning you have a unified and secure space for your document management and storage. We designed Docs to be a clean, simple experience. With Docs you can:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Write with privacy </strong>—<strong> </strong>Create and edit documents within Proton Drive, knowing your contents are only accessible to you and those you choose to share with.</li>



<li><strong>Share and invite anyone —</strong> Invite other users to view or edit your documents with a single click.</li>



<li><strong>Collaborate in real-time </strong>— Changes are reflected immediately, ensuring every contributor always sees the most up-to-date version.</li>



<li><strong>View cursors and presence indicators</strong> — See who else is viewing or editing the document, enhancing teamwork and communication.</li>



<li><strong>Leave comments and replies </strong>— Add comments to share feedback without editing the document. Comments are visible to all collaborators, keeping everyone in the loop.</li>



<li><strong>Import and export with ease — </strong>You can upload .docx documents, edit them, and download in various formats like .docx, .txt, .md, and HTML.</li>
</ul>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img width="2401" height="1200" data-public-id="wp-pme/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x.png" loading="lazy" decoding="async" src="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_2401,h_1200,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1719985722/wp-pme/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x.png?_i=AA" alt="" class="wp-post-75839 wp-image-75844" data-format="png" data-transformations="f_auto,q_auto" data-filesize="1 MB" data-optsize="137 KB" data-optformat="image/webp" data-percent="87.7" data-permalink="https://pme.protonblog.tech/wp-admin/admin.php?page=cloudinary&amp;section=edit-asset&amp;asset=75844" data-version="1719985722" data-seo="1" srcset="https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1024,h_512,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1719985722/wp-pme/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x.png?_i=AA 1024w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_300,h_150,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1719985722/wp-pme/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x.png?_i=AA 300w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_768,h_384,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1719985722/wp-pme/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x.png?_i=AA 768w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1536,h_768,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1719985722/wp-pme/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x.png?_i=AA 1536w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_2048,h_1024,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1719985722/wp-pme/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x.png?_i=AA 2048w, https://res.cloudinary.com/dbulfrlrz/images/w_1568,h_784,c_scale/f_auto,q_auto/v1719985722/wp-pme/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x/proton-docs-blog-2-collaboration2x.png?_i=AA 1568w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">A complete privacy-first ecosystem</h2>



<p>Far too often, online productivity suites require you to accept surveillance as a condition of use. Docs is a milestone in our journey to building a better internet where privacy is the default. It is the first collaborative document editor that combines open source end-to-end encryption within a secure ecosystem that includes email, cloud storage, calendar, and more, so you can break away from Big Tech services that exploit your data. This is another important step toward advancing the mission of the <a href="https://proton.me/foundation" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">nonprofit Proton Foundation.</a></p>



<p>With Proton Drive and Docs, you now have a secure, privacy-first cloud storage and productivity alternative. If you’re working in law firms or healthcare, you can draft contracts and manage patient data in compliance with privacy laws. Journalists, content creators, and entrepreneurs can keep their projects protected from data leaks and Big Tech surveillance (no AI snooping on your work). Whether for work or for personal use, Proton Drive ensures your documents remain safe and private.</p>



<p>We&#8217;re excited to see how you will benefit from the robust privacy protections that Docs offer. Ready to get started? <a href="https://account.proton.me/drive/signup?plan=free">Check out Docs in Proton Drive</a> and start collaborating privately.</p>



<p><strong>To get the best experience in Docs, please be sure to <a href="https://proton.me/drive/download" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">update your Proton Drive app</a> to the latest version on desktop and mobile.</strong></p>

   <title>
    Is it safe to let your password manager autofill your password?
   </title>
   <link/>

   <guid ispermalink="true">
    https://proton.me/blog/safe-to-autofill-passwords

   <description>
    Using autofill to complete online forms is fast and easy, but be aware of hacking tactics that exploit this convenience.
   </description>
   <pubdate>
    Tue, 02 Jul 2024 04:49:03 GMT
   </pubdate>
   <content:encoded>
    <p>Struggling to keep track of all your passwords? You’re not the only one. <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-a-password-manager" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Password managers</a> exist because it’s difficult to keep track of hundreds of logins and all their various passwords. It’s likely you have saved passwords on your devices for convenience: You might use the password manager built into your browser, software offered by a third party, or one of the cloud-based password managers working across multiple devices like <a href="https://proton.me/blog/is-icloud-keychain-safe" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">iCloud</a>.</p>



<p>A good password manager can <a href="https://proton.me/pass/password-generator" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">suggest secure passwords</a>, store all of your login credentials safely, and then autofill fields instantly so you don’t need to type in your login details each time. They’re a very useful tool, and one that can help you strengthen your online safety if used correctly. However, there are some safety tips you should be aware of if you want to stay extra secure. In this article we’ll focus on how password autofill can affect your online security. </p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Is using a password manager safe?</h2>



<p>First, let’s understand how a password manager works. Think of your password manager like a bank vault: It’s full of valuable resources, and both you and your service provider are responsible for protecting access to it. You can protect yourself by creating a <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-passphrase" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">strong master password or passphrase</a> and using <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-two-factor-authentication-2fa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">two-factor authentication (2FA)</a>. Your password manager can then store and protect those passwords. </p>



<p>One of the ways a password manager protects your data is by encrypting it using an <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-encryption" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">encryption algorithm</a>. All your logins, passwords, payment methods, notes and other data will only be accessible to you and the password manager’s servers. Some services offer the more secure option of <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-end-to-end-encryption" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">end-to-end encryption</a>, which prevents the company from accessing your data and ensuring only you can see it. When you’re choosing a password manager, it’s safest to choose one which offers end-to-end encryption, <a href="https://proton.me/blog/proton-pass-security-model" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">including of metadata</a>. Proton Pass offers <a href="https://proton.me/pass/security" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">end-to-end encryption</a> which makes all of your data and metadata unreadable when it’s stored in your vault. No-one can access it, not even Proton. </p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">How does password autofill work?</h2>



<p>Autofill is a feature in many password managers that lets you automatically populate fields on a website so you don’t have to manually type them in. Fields can include your username and password, but also your bank card details, 2FA code, and other data.</p>



<p>Generally speaking, password autofill is either automated or manual. When autofill is automated, your saved login and password will populate in the relevant fields of a website you’ve saved credentials for. When autofill is manual, your password manager will wait for you to interact with the fields by clicking or typing before it will autofill your password.&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Password autofill risks</h2>



<p>Using automated password autofill means you don’t have to think about entering your credentials, but this is risky. Autofill will automatically fill <em>any </em>field on a webpage without your permission. For example, a malicious landing page may have multiple invisible fields which hackers can use to convince your password manager to autofill with your credentials. This can happen without your knowledge, and multiple passwords can be compromised by a single landing page.&nbsp;</p>



<p>This is a well-known attack called an <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/daveywinder/2023/12/11/android-warning-1password-dashlane-lastpass-and-others-can-leak-passwords/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">AutoSpill exploit</a>. In 2023, many password managers were confirmed to have been compromised using this exact exploit, including 1Password, LastPass, Enpass, Keeper, and Keepass2Android. It’s a vulnerability that many password managers simply didn’t have a rigorous enough autofill policy to combat. </p>



<p><strong>But it’s actually incredibly easy to avoid.</strong> All you need to do is turn on manual autofill.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Your password manager will always run background checks, examining the domain and verifying that no phishing elements are present. But using manual autofill creates an extra layer of security because it gives you a chance to check that you’re on the right website.&nbsp;</p>



<p><a href="https://proton.me/pass">Proton Pass</a> uses manual autofill by default and only populates fields on domains you already trust.&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">How can I keep my passwords safe?&nbsp;</h2>



<p>Ultimately, it’s up to you to make sure you’re staying safe online. One of the best ways you can do that is to use a trusted, <a href="https://proton.me/pass">secure password manager</a>. Along with manual autofill, end-to-end encryption, and secure password suggestion, reliable password management software should offer:</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">The option to create passkeys</h3>



<p><a href="https://proton.me/pass/passkeys" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Passkeys</a> make it possible for you to verify your identity online without using a password or passphrase. This means that instead of using a specific password, you can create a digital credential that’s tied to your logged in device. In effect, your password manager becomes the authenticator rather than your password. This is sometimes a more secure option than a password, but not every platform supports them. <strong>Proton Pass gives you the option to use passkeys when available.</strong></p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Proactive protection</h3>



<p>In the background, your password manager needs to be aware of data breaches and potentially compromised websites. <a href="https://proton.me/pass/pass-monitor" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Pass Monitor in Proton Pass</a> scans the dark web for you to ensure none of your credentials have leaked, flagging any weak or repeated passwords, and preventing hackers from ever being able to access your account even if they’ve acquired some of your information. </p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Identity management</h3>



<p>Your personal email address is almost like your online passport. A good password manager will not only protect the data and metadata that you save, it’ll help you <a href="https://proton.me/pass/aliases" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">create email aliases</a> which forward emails into your inbox. Proton Pass easily generates hide-my-email aliases that can’t be connected to you, putting an extra layer of safety between hackers and your personal email address. If an alias address is compromised, all you’ll need to do is deactivate it. </p>



<p>Proton Pass is the only password manager that offers complete identity protection, using end-to-end encryption built by scientists at CERN. With Proton Pass, you’ll have access to:</p>



<ul>
<li>A built-in 2FA authenticator</li>



<li>Passkey authentication</li>



<li>Email aliases</li>



<li>Dark web and data breach scanning with <a href="https://proton.me/pass/pass-monitor" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Pass Monitor</a> (available in Pass Plus)</li>



<li>Defense against account takeovers with <a href="https://proton.me/blog/sentinel-included-pass-plus" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Pass Sentinel</a> (available in Pass Plus)</li>



<li><a href="https://proton.me/pass/password-sharing" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Secure password sharing</a></li>



<li>Support for unlimited devices, logins, and notes</li>
</ul>



<p>Take the first step in protecting your passwords today. <a href="https://account.proton.me/pass/signup">Get Proton Pass.</a></p>

    <p><a href="https://protonvpn.com/blog/types-of-cyberattacks">Cyberattacks</a> aren&#8217;t always executed through sophisticated methods like man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks on <a href="https://protonvpn.com/blog/public-wifi-safety">public WiFi</a>. Sometimes, they rely on something as simple as looking over your shoulder.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Shoulder surfing attacks are when someone watches you enter sensitive information on your device and uses it to gain unauthorized access. It&#8217;s a reminder that despite our advanced technology, we still need simple precautions to stay safe.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Shoulder surfing meaning</h2>



<p>Shoulder surfing is a type of <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-social-engineering">social engineering</a> attack in which the attacker physically spies on someone to obtain confidential information such as passwords, PINs, or other sensitive data. This can be done by watching someone or listening to confidential information being spoken (eavesdropping).</p>



<p>A thief could be directly observing you from close distance or use sophisticated methods, such as binoculars, hidden cameras, or smartphones, to capture your information from a distance and remain undetected.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">How shoulder surfing can affect you</h2>



<p>Shoulder surfing attacks can have serious consequences. For example, if a thief sees your email and password, they can use them to hack into your accounts, <a href="https://proton.me/blog/types-of-identity-theft">steal your identity</a>, or sell your information on the <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-dark-web">dark web</a>.</p>



<p>By getting hold of your <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-to-do-if-someone-has-your-social-security-number">Social Security number</a>, home address, and birthday, a criminal could make unauthorized purchases, open new credit cards, apply for loans, or even commit crimes using your name. You would then have to deal with the fallout by trying to prove that it wasn&#8217;t you.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Examples of shoulder surfing</h2>



<p>Shoulder surfing usually happens in public, crowded places because attackers can easily blend in and discreetly observe people entering sensitive information without arousing suspicion. Here are some examples:</p>



<ul>
<li>In <strong>cafes</strong>, people often use laptops, tablets, and smartphones for personal or work-related tasks, so a shoulder surfer might sit at a nearby table or walk past repeatedly. In 2019, a group of about 25 young women were <a href="https://www.brusselstimes.com/85310/members-of-a-gang-of-shoulder-surfers-arrested-in-amsterdam">arrested</a> in Amsterdam for shoulder surfing in more than 100 incidents.</li>



<li><strong>Airports </strong>are filled with travelers frequently using their devices to check flight details, access banking services, or respond to work emails. A shoulder surfer could stand behind you in a queue.</li>



<li><strong>Buses, trains, and subways</strong> are crowded with passengers sitting closely next to each other. A shoulder surfer could sit or stand next to you or behind you. A 2017 <a href="https://www.medien.ifi.lmu.de/pubdb/publications/pub/eiband2017chi/eiband2017chi.pdf">study</a> by LMU Munich found that 67% of shoulder surfing happens on public transport.</li>



<li><strong>Shared workspaces</strong> used by freelancers and remote employees are risky because you are often surrounded by strangers who could easily observe your screen while pretending to work on their devices.</li>



<li>Criminals frequently target <strong>ATMs</strong> to capture PIN entries using binoculars or pinhole cameras without being noticed. For example, a man in LA was <a href="https://www.justice.gov/usao-cdca/pr/la-man-convicted-atm-shoulder-surfing-allowed-him-withdraw-cash-after-bank-customers">convicted</a> of ATM shoulder surfing in 2018 for obtaining the PINs of unsuspecting bank customers.</li>



<li>At <strong>checkout counters</strong>, especially during busy times, shoppers often enter their PINs or credit card information. A shoulder surfer might pose as another customer, closely observing the keypad as someone enters their details, or even use their smartphone to covertly record the information.</li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">How to prevent shoulder surfing</h2>



<p>Staying alert is important to avoid shoulder surfing attacks, but there are many specific ways to protect your privacy and security.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Be strategic with your surroundings</h3>



<p>Whenever you’re working with sensitive data in a public place, <strong>position yourself in a way that minimizes exposure to prying eyes</strong>, such as sitting with your back to a wall. You can also use a physical barrier, such as a privacy hood or screen shield, to block others&#8217; views.</p>



<p><strong>Shield your personal information</strong> when entering your PIN at an ATM or grocery shop by covering it with your hand or moving your body. Avoid using your devices or disclosing sensitive information over the phone until you reach a less crowded area.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Make your devices more private</h3>



<p>In addition to being aware of your surroundings, you can make your device harder to look at. Rotate your device&#8217;s screen away from potential onlookers behind or next to you. <strong>Dimming your screen</strong> can make it harder for others to see your display from a distance.</p>



<p>In your device settings, you can <strong>configure your screen to auto-lock after being inactive for a couple minutes</strong>. This is safer than 15 or 30 minutes, which is the default on many devices. That way if you leave your phone out or leave it behind, you’re less likely to have someone break into it.</p>



<p>Additionally, <strong>turn off notification previews on your lock screen</strong> to prevent sensitive information from being seen by others around you.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Improve your data security</h3>



<p>Your logins are your first line of defense against attacks. Create <a href="https://proton.me/blog/auto-generate-password" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">strong, unique passwords</a> since these are harder for shoulder surfers to catch and write down. <strong>Avoid reusing passwords across different accounts to minimize damage</strong> in case of <a href="https://proton.me/blog/breach-recommendations" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">data leaks</a> and prevent <a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-credential-stuffing-attack" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">credential stuffing attacks</a>. If you suspect you might have been a victim of shoulder surfing, change your passwords immediately.</p>



<p>Crucially, you should <strong>enable </strong><a href="https://proton.me/blog/what-is-two-factor-authentication-2fa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><strong>two-factor authentication (2FA)</strong></a><strong> on all your accounts</strong> that support it. By requiring a second identification factor (a code on your authenticator app), you ensure that even if someone learns your password, they still wouldn’t be able to pass the second mode of verification. 2FA is particularly secure because the code changes frequently, making it much harder for anyone to steal and use it.</p>



<p>Set up fraud alerts and regularly check your bank statements and credit reports for any unauthorized activity. <strong>Monitor the web to see if your data was leaked</strong>, and take action if necessary.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">How Proton Pass makes these steps easier</h2>



<p>Proton Pass is a secure password manager that can remember all your passwords and auto-fills them on any device, so you’ll never be caught by a shoulder surfer watching your keystrokes.&nbsp;</p>



<p>It generates random, complex passwords, as well as <a href="https://proton.me/support/pass-use-passkeys" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">passkeys</a> to log in to online accounts without passwords.</p>



<p>Proton Pass also includes a <a href="https://proton.me/support/pass-2fa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">built-in 2FA authenticator</a> to use with all your accounts that support 2FA. You can also use <a href="https://proton.me/pass/pass-monitor" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Pass Monitor</a> to audit the security of all your accounts — it includes Password Health, which checks for weak or reused accounts, and Dark Web Monitoring, which notifies you immediately if your personal information is leaked on the web.</p>



<p>We protect your data with <a href="https://proton.me/security/end-to-end-encryption" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">end-to-end encryption</a> to ensure no one can read your data — not even us. All our apps are <a href="https://proton.me/community/open-source" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">open source</a> and independently audited.</p>



<p>Improve your online privacy and security by <a href="https://proton.me/pass">subscribing for a free Proton Pass account</a>.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Frequently asked questions</h2>



<div class="schema-faq wp-block-yoast-faq-block"><div class="schema-faq-section" id="faq-question-1719206918693"><strong class="schema-faq-question">What does no shoulder surfing mean?</strong> <p class="schema-faq-answer">&#8220;No shoulder surfing&#8221; means taking precautions to prevent people from looking over your shoulder to see sensitive information you are entering on a device, such as passwords, PINs, or other private data. It signifies being aware of your surroundings and ensuring that no one can easily view your screen or keyboard to steal your personal information.</p> </div> <div class="schema-faq-section" id="faq-question-1719206934921"><strong class="schema-faq-question">Is it illegal to shoulder surf?</strong> <p class="schema-faq-answer">While the act of merely watching someone might not be a crime in itself, using that information to steal someone&#8217;s identity, commit fraud, or gain unauthorized access to accounts or data is illegal. Any form of data theft or unauthorized access to personal information is considered a criminal act.</p> </div> <div class="schema-faq-section" id="faq-question-1719206944494"><strong class="schema-faq-question">What is the difference between shoulder surfing and dumpster surfing?</strong> <p class="schema-faq-answer">Shoulder surfing involves directly observing someone to obtain sensitive information by looking over their shoulder, usually in public places. In contrast, dumpster surfing (or dumpster diving) means to look into trash bins or dumpsters for valuable information like documents or electronic devices.</p> </div> </div>

    Proton receives ISO 27001 certification
   </title>

   <description>
    In May 2024, Proton received an ISO 27001 certification, highlighting our commitment to security and user privacy. Here’s what comes next.
   </description>
   <pubdate>
    Thu, 20 Jun 2024 14:57:53 GMT
   </pubdate>
   <content:encoded>
    <p>Proton prioritizes our community’s privacy and data security in every aspect of our business.&nbsp;</p>



<p>To further demonstrate our commitment, we underwent a rigorous external audit and – on May 2, 2024 – received our <a href="https://www.iso.org/standard/27001" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">ISO 27001</a> certification. </p>



<p>As an organization founded by scientists who met at CERN, we see peer review and transparency as a cornerstone of our mission. That&#8217;s why we make all our apps open source, allowing anyone to examine our code.</p>



<p>Here&#8217;s what this latest certification means and what’s next for Proton.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">How we did it&nbsp;</h2>



<p>At Proton, our philosophy is to focus first on good security and let compliance with standards and frameworks follow.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Our philosophy was confirmed by the fact that, to comply with ISO 27001:2022, we only needed to formalize and document some of our current processes. No fundamental changes in how our business or teams operate were required. </p>



<p>This comprehensive audit spanned 14 days and involved over 15 dedicated teams, each thoroughly evaluating the information security management systems underlying all Proton products.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>



<p>Basically, our security management operations were double-checked and validated by independent experts.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Why we did it&nbsp;</h2>



<p>At Proton, we believe in building products our community can trust. We also believe that trust must be earned. As an organization founded and run by former scientists, we believe all claims must be not only investigated but verified, including our own</p>



<p>Transparency and peer review are the best ways to ensure systems function as they&#8217;re supposed to and vulnerabilities are quickly resolved. This approach only becomes more important as we grow and add new services. This certification not only proves our methodology is sound, it makes it easier for us to work with larger organizations in the future.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We pursued this certification for the same reason we open our products to scrutiny through external penetration tests and our <a href="https://proton.me/security/bug-bounty">bug bounty program</a>: To ensure any vulnerabilities in our service are swiftly identified and resolved so your information remains safe.&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">What&#8217;s next&nbsp;</h2>



<p>Looking ahead, we plan to strengthen support for our business customers, particularly those handling sensitive data, by publishing further information and audit reports detailing our security controls.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Thank you for being part of our mission to build a better internet where privacy is the default. Stay tuned for more updates and new features designed to keep your data safe and secure.</p>
